results:
I found several relevant search results about Donald Tusk's controversial tweet referencing "Folwark zwierzęcy" (Animal Farm) in the context of Polish politics. Here's what the search revealed:

## Donald Tusk's "Animal Farm" Reference in Polish Politics

Donald Tusk posted a controversial tweet in September 2021 that read: "Folwark zwierzęcy po polsku, czyli jak dwa wieprze na rozkaz kaczora miały przy pomocy jednej krowy odwrócić uwagę od stada tłustych kotów" (Animal Farm in Polish: how two pigs on the order of a drake were supposed to use one cow to divert attention from a herd of fat cats).

### Context and Reactions

The tweet was Tusk's response to a controversial press conference by ministers Mariusz Błaszczak and Mariusz Kamiński, during which they presented controversial photos allegedly found on migrants' phones. According to OKO.press, one of the photos showing a man with an animal was actually a screenshot from an old internet video featuring a mare, not a cow.

Tusk concluded his tweet with the disclaimer: "Wszelkie podobieństwo do prawdziwych postaci jest przypadkowe" (Any resemblance to real persons is coincidental).

### Political Responses

The tweet sparked strong reactions across the political spectrum:

Paweł Szrot, head of the president's cabinet, criticized the post, calling it "dehumanization of the opponent" and comparing it to Joseph Goebbels' tactics, stating that "publicly calling people pigs is simply vile".

PiS Secretary General Krzysztof Sobolewski posted a screenshot comparing Tusk's tweet with an identical post from a Twitter account called SokzBuraka, writing "Find the difference - Troll from Brussels vs. sokzburaka set the program for the party of shame".

### Literary Analysis

One commentator noted that Orwell probably wouldn't be pleased with this temporary popularity in Poland, as his book was an allegory of the Bolshevik revolution. The same writer reflected on how political discourse has changed, noting that while political happenings used to be amusing, with age comes a demand for seriousness and solutions from leaders.

The incident highlights the ongoing polarization in Polish politics and the use of literary references as political weapons in contemporary discourse between PiS (Law and Justice) and opposition parties led by Tusk.
